On Sat, 16 Jul 2005 07:16:51 -0500, Ashot Petrosian <ashot@...> wrote:

> On Wed, 13 Jul 2005 07:12:14 -0000, Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...> wrote:
>
>> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Colin Green <cgreen@d...> wrote:
>>> Here are some nice 3D graphs of test functions for a GA toolkit.
>> There
>>> are some very simple shapes and some more complex, now image a
>> network
>>> were each output node described one of these functions (assuming x,y
>>> inputs)  - how complex would a network need to be to describe these?
>>>
>>> http://www.systemtechnik.tu-
>> ilmenau.de/~pohlheim/GA_Toolbox/fcnindex.html
>>> <http://www.systemtechnik.tu-ilmenau.de/%
>> 7Epohlheim/GA_Toolbox/fcnindex.html>
>>
>> I think function approximation is probably a fairly good benchmark if
>> you can find a nice set of functions for a test suite.
>>
>> ken
>
> 	I'd just like to say that it would be nice if we no longer had benchmarks which were defined as the task only, sans the fitness function.  The fitness function has so much to do in shaping the landscape that I don't understand how its sensible to say something like "we can solve the ___ task."  It is essentially possible to cheat to solve a task by constructing a fitness function which is multi-tiered and points the algorithm in the right direction to the solution for most complicated problems, right?  Or am I just crazy?
>
>

I should say that I think function approximation would is a good idea, that wasn't in response to that but just a general comment on a benchmarking pet pieve, sorry.
